dublinCore.description: Interactive simulation demonstrating Newton's Third Law through six real-world scenarios: book on table, hammer and nail, rocket propulsion, swimming, Earth-Moon gravitation, and car acceleration. Each scenario visualizes action-reaction force pairs with animated graphics and explanatory panels.

educational.topic: Newton's Third Law, Action-Reaction Pairs, Force Interactions
learningObjectives: Identify action-reaction force pairs in various physical situations
Explain why action-reaction pairs do not cancel each other out
Distinguish between contact forces and gravitational forces
Apply Newton's Third Law to explain rocket propulsion
Recognize that action-reaction pairs act on different objects
Understand that action-reaction forces are equal in magnitude and opposite in direction
educational.prerequisites: Basic understanding of forces, Newton's First and Second Laws

scenarios: Book on Table: Two action-reaction pairs (gravity, contact)
Hammer and Nail: Equal forces, different masses
Rocket in Space: Propulsion via momentum conservation
Swimming: Push water back, move forward
Car Accelerating: Tire pushes ground, ground pushes tire
keyPrinciples: Action-reaction pairs are always equal in magnitude
Action-reaction pairs always act on different objects
Action-reaction pairs are always the same type of force
Weight and normal force are NOT an action-reaction pair

commonMisconceptions: Action-reaction forces cancel out (they act on different objects)
Larger objects exert larger forces (forces are always equal)
Weight and normal force are an action-reaction pair (they're not)
You need something to push against to move (rockets work in vacuum)
assessmentOpportunities: Identify the two objects involved in each action-reaction pair
Explain why a hammer drives a nail despite equal forces
Describe how a rocket moves in the vacuum of space
Distinguish between action-reaction pairs and balanced forces
realWorldApplications: Sports: pushing off in running, jumping, skating
